attributes.alt: Cover for Push and Pull by Cody Crane. Cover shows a girl pulling a wagon with two boys in it as a girl pushes the wagon from behind.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background, sing a push/pull song, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
What things can move with a push?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Understand and use category words; Understand and use a growing number of science words.
Use complete sentences of four or more words.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.
Show children picture cards of different items that they can move by pushing or pulling.
Have children sort the items into a “Push” and a “Pull” pile.
How can we make things go?
What is being pushed or pulled in your book?
Pretend you are trying to move something that’s very heavy.
Can you find something in the classroom that moves fast?
Draw a picture of something that moves slow.
What makes something easy to move?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the words
Can you say a word that begins with that letter?
Can you use blocks to make something that is easy to push?

attributes.alt: Cover for Push and Pull by Cody Crane. Cover shows a girl pulling a wagon with two boys in it as a girl pushes the wagon from behind.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Understand and use category words; Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions; Understand and use a growing number of science words.
Use complete sentences of four or more words.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts.
Have children play with toy cars to find different ways they can make the cars move.
Have children observe ways to speed up, slow down, stop, and change the direction of their toy cars.
How can we make things go?
Can you show something in a book that you could pull to move?
Show how you would lift something that is heavy.
Can you find three things in the room that are easy to move?
Can you draw a picture of something that moves very fast?
Can you make a big wave in the ocean?
Can you push three letters together to make the word
Can you make a rocket out of blocks?

attributes.alt: Cover for Push and Pull by Cody Crane. Cover shows a girl pulling a wagon with two boys in it as a girl pushes the wagon from behind.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill
What things can move with a pull?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Understand and use category words; Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places things, and actions; Understand and use a growing number of science words.
Use complete sentences of four or more words.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.
Review with children pictures of moving people, animals, and objects and talk about how fast or slow they are moving.
Have children sort the cards by slow and fast.
How can we make things go?
Which characters in the book move fast? Which move slow?
Pretend you are doing everything really slow.
Compare how fast two different-sized balls fall to the ground.
Draw a picture of a fast animal.
What animal moves slow? Can you draw it?
What letter makes the sound that you hear at the beginning of the word
Can you build a really fast car out of blocks? How will you show that it’s really fast?

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas for The Great Big Enormous Yuca. Six images show an old man, an old woman, Ana, a dog, and a mouse pulling a yuca from the ground.
Cover for Push and Pull by Cody Crane. Cover shows a girl pulling a wagon with two boys in it as a girl pushes the wagon from behind.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about what children have learned about how things move and introduce vocabulary words
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Read interactively and connect to this week’s concept question,
How can we make things move?
Understand and use category words; Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions; Understand and use a growing number of science words.
Use complete sentences of four or more words.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.
Show children picture cards and have them decide whether they can move what is shown.
Have children offer strategies for moving the objects they cannot move.
How can we make things go?
Can you find a character in the book who can move very fast?
Pretend you are moving like a cat. How fast or slow would you move?
Can you put five animals in order from slowest to fastest?
Draw the enormous yuca after it was pulled from the ground.
Can you create a story about the people who helped the old man pull the yuca out of the ground?
Can you show me what letter makes the beginning sound you hear in the word
? What other word begins with the same sound?
Can you build something enormous out of blocks?
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Push and Pull by Cody Crane. Copyright © 2019 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.

attributes.alt: Cover for Push and Pull by Cody Crane. Cover shows a girl pulling a wagon with two boys in it as a girl pushes the wagon from behind.

elements.text: Use Circle Time for a movement activity and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
What can happen when something is moving?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions; Understand and use a growing number of science words.
Understand and use varied types of words.
Use complete sentences of four or more words.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.
Use different art materials for exploration and sensory experience.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
If you had to move a large object, what would it be and how would you move it?
Save children’s writing to display next week.
How can we make things go?
What animals are fast? What animals are slow?
Pretend you are carrying a really heavy box.
See how fast you can make toy cars go.
Make up a story where everything moves backwards, and draw a picture of it.
Can you imagine a machine that helps you jump really high? Can you draw it?
What letter do you hear at the beginning of the word
Can you build a ramp out of blocks for toy cars?
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Push and Pull by Cody Crane. Copyright © 2019 by Scholastic Inc. Published by Scholastic Inc.

Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Typically use complete sentences of four or more words and grammatical complexity, usually with subject, verb, and object orders.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss position and motion of objects.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.

Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss position and motion of objects.
Coordinate sequence of movements to perform tasks.

Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
